name: NPR
text:
Stock prices plummeted Wednesday, amid fears that a spike in coronavirus cases in parts of the country could force the economy into another lockdown.
https://t.co/jwMc9OnJdO

name: NPR
text:
More and more cyclists are taking on “Everesting” — climbing the height equal to Mount Everest by riding a single hill, up and down, over and over again. 

Lachlan Morton just set a record: He finished in seven hours, 29 minutes and 57 seconds.
https://t.co/VB9wIEV1B5

name: NPR
text:
"Very few Americans have created all of their wealth on their own; it's passed down through generations and then built upon," journalist @nhannahjones says.

"You cannot close a racial wealth gap without transferring wealth."
https://t.co/yJTaCj3L3A

name: NPR
text:
Anti-racist protests in Washington State were not a catalyst for the spread of COVID-19, according to a state public health official. 

"What we're finding is, in large part, that's due to the use of masks," she said.
https://t.co/nqtrMns9LF

name: NPR
text:
Several governors, largely in the South and West, have opted to postpone the next phase of their states' reopening in light of growing coronavirus cases and hospitalization numbers.
https://t.co/CB2FAhQNC4

name: NPR
text:
New daily coronavirus cases are rising in 27 states, an NPR analysis shows. 

Here's the percent change compared to 2 weeks ago:

Oklahoma: +255%
Idaho: +176%
Florida: +173%
Arizona: +173%
Texas: +169%
https://t.co/EnrxwdSqtO

name: NPR
text: Some camps and day cares are still giving kids social experiences this summer — from a distance. That means no hugs or high-fives, no big group activities, no field trips, no swimming. (@WBEZ) https://t.co/KxbQ3i72Jj

name: NPR
text:
Electronic artist @jamesblake has spent a lot of time on Instagram Live, playing concerts for thousands.

“Club music takes up a different part of the brain,” Blake says. “I, for one, will be definitely undernourished until we're able to do it again.”
https://t.co/caF8KknJOe

name: NPR
text:
Barack Obama told supporters they need to do more to ensure Joe Biden wins the 2020 presidential race. 

"Whatever you've done so far is not enough. And I hold myself and Michelle and my kids to the same standard," he said Tuesday.
https://t.co/OQTZrWM4go

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden will formally accept the nomination at the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee in August, but state delegations have been told to conduct business remotely.
https://t.co/vNEcM9goGf

name: NPR
text:
Naida Lavon was furloughed from her job because of the pandemic — then lost her housing. Now, she lives out of her minivan as she navigates the changing world around her.
https://t.co/o8Dnc2Labo

name: NPR
text:
Montana now has the lowest coronavirus infection rate in the country.

And the pandemic ⁠— and Gov. Steve Bullock's handling of it ⁠— is fast becoming a central issue in his campaign to unseat Republican Sen. Steve Daines.
 https://t.co/rRneiTDRjZ

name: NPR
text:
Today the House and Senate are back in session, at the same time, for the first time since the pandemic began. But access to coronavirus testing remains limited.
https://t.co/9Haak9fnGF

name: NPR
text:
The Los Angeles Times has been hit with a proposed class-action lawsuit — contending that under-representation of people of color at the paper is a result of longstanding discriminatory pay practices against Black, Hispanic and female journalists.
https://t.co/fNGdAG6A4I

name: NPR
text:
Kent County, Michigan — where former President Gerald Ford grew up — has long been Republican turf. But it's also a suburban community that Democrats think they can win in November.
https://t.co/0hWl8ZsouG

name: NPR
text:
Three former staffers of a Michigan youth home have been charged in the death of Cornelius Fredericks —  a Black 16-year-old who died after employees sat on his chest, abdomen and legs to restrain him.

A lawyer said he repeatedly cried: "I can't breathe."
https://t.co/60VzcQ02WA
